bug.short_desc: add inline comment dialog should be non-modal and resizable

long_desc.thetext: To improve usability, the add inline comment dialog should be non-modal and resizable.

Review: https://git.eclipse.org/r/#/c/13247/
I think the dialog is missing a title and an info for which line it has been opened (which is more important now, once it's non-modal)
Created attachment 231583 mylyn/context/zip
Tomek, could you attach a screenshot of what the dialog looks like now?
I mean with your change.

Created attachment 231643 Screenshot of the "Add Comment" dialog
The change makes the dialog non-modal and resizable so it's hard to spot a difference. I highlighted other areas which I think could be improved: title, description, font.
Yeah, it would make sense to include the line number or something in the description, and there should be a title too. How should the font be changed?

(In reply to comment #6) > How should the font be changed?
I would use a fixed width font, just like in EGit commit comment. But I'm not strongly attached to this idea.

The EGit commit dialog and staging view don't use a fixed width font (at least not with my configuration). I don't see any reason to use a different font than is used in the task editor (which is configurable on the fonts preference page). In fact I wonder if we should consider supporting wikitext for inline comments.

(In reply to comment #8) > The EGit commit dialog and staging view don't use a fixed width font (at > least not with my configuration). I don't see any reason to use a different > font than is used in the task editor (which is configurable on the fonts > preference page).
Ok, forget about it then.
> In fact I wonder if we should consider supporting wikitext > for inline comments.
Sounds like a great idea.

Sounds cool guys. I haven't been able to look at the review yet. Are you hoping to get this into Kepler? If not, for UI work it might be better to focus on bug 409418 as that is something we really should have to introduce users to a key feature.

Since this seems like a trivial change which will be a significant improvement, I would like to get it into Kepler. If there are issues having multiple dialogs open, perhaps we could simply prevent that.
We can no longer accept contributions for Kepler. Sorry. This will have to wait for an SR or go into the next release stream.
Oh well.

Sorry, guys. I should have made that connection earlier. I think it's still very much worthwhile for SR1, but in any case we do have to focus on these basic usability issues. The best contribution right now is to help with reviewing fixes (coming soon) for those issues.
Marking as enhancement. Tomek, let me know if you want to restart review on this..
Why would I want to restart it, I thought it's in progress. Sam gave it +1 already. Would you like me to rebase it or something?
I meant because we're outside of the Kepler window and we can accept your contributions again. So yeah, if you want to rebase it, I'd be happy to take a look as well.
Rebased, as wished.

Thanks Tomek. After playing around with it a bit, I'm not so sure that making the dialog non-modal is a good change. I do like the message and resizing. Here's the issue I see.. The add comment dialog is already not well-associated with what you're commenting on. By making the comment dialog non-modal, you're making the situation worse, because the user can then click to a different window and you lose the context. (Though having the message helps here.) It's also just not clear to me why you'd want to have more than one of these open, or do other things while editing a comment.
Small nit; for enhancements, I like to avoid using words like "should" in favor of neutral language like "make inline comment dialog non-modal and resizeable"..but maybe that's just me.

I find it extremely frustrating that I can't copy text from the compare editor and other places into the inline comment dialog. Usually I open the dialog, start typing, and then want to copy some code or something, but then I have no easy way to do that without losing whatever I just typed. For me, this is a majore usability problem.
As I mentioned before, we might want to prevent the user from opening a second inline comment dialog at the same time.

(In reply to comment #20) > I find it extremely frustrating that I can't copy text from the compare editor > and other places into the inline comment dialog.
Oh yeah, I see what you mean. In general, I don't like modal dialogs if they can be avoided.
> As I mentioned before, we might want to prevent the user from opening a second > inline comment dialog at the same time.
I guess I'm just wondering how much time we should spend on this given that the basic workflow should be changed altogether. That is, we should have support for quick inline comments ala the Web UI, etc..

(In reply to comment #8) > The EGit commit dialog and staging view don't use a fixed width font (at least > not with my configuration). I don't see any reason to use a different font than > is used in the task editor (which is configurable on the fonts preference page). > In fact I wonder if we should consider supporting wikitext for inline comments.
Wait, we already do, or at least should. We built that last year along w/ spell check. I wonder if it got lost somehow..or maybe we just had it for global comments..

See bug 390374 (In reply to comment #22) > (In reply to comment #8) > > In fact I wonder if we should consider supporting wikitext for inline > comments.
https://git.eclipse.org/r/#/c/13966/ See bug 390374 comment 4. This was accidently deleted from plugin. But it still doesn't seem to be working for some reason.

(In reply to comment #21) > (In reply to comment #20) > > I find it extremely frustrating that I can't copy text from the compare editor > > and other places into the inline comment dialog. > > Oh yeah, I see what you mean. In general, I don't like modal dialogs if they can > be avoided. > > > As I mentioned before, we might want to prevent the user from opening a second > > inline comment dialog at the same time. > > I guess I'm just wondering how much time we should spend on this given that the > basic workflow should be changed altogether. That is, we should have support for > quick inline comments ala the Web UI, etc..
If that's hard to do then I wouldn't bother with it, but I still think the dialog should be non-modal to make this more usable for now.

(In reply to comment #24) > (In reply to comment #21) > > I guess I'm just wondering how much time we should spend on this given that > the > > basic workflow should be changed altogether. That is, we should have support > for > > quick inline comments ala the Web UI, etc.. > > If that's hard to do then I wouldn't bother with it, but I still think the > dialog should be non-modal to make this more usable for now.
I guess I'm still just -1/2 on this. My primary concern is that you can click away from the editor, which is just weird. Consider for example the GoTo line wizard. What about doing something like offering to dismiss if the user activates another editor? I guess there just isn't a simple solution for this one. I'd rather have the add comment in a View peronally, but I know that idea isn't likely to be popular. ;)
This doesn't prevent us from doing something better in the future. I'm not really seeing a good reason to make the dialog modal.

Ok, I don't want to be a PITA about this or turn it into an epic, but here's another issue, which I have to bring up even though I just went through this annouyance myself. What happens if the user actually closes the editor while in the midst of editing a comment. Surprisingly, it actually works, but it does seem sort of odd.
Note that other process oriented dialogs like Git Commit are modal..
I think a better comparison would be the task attachment dialog, which is non-modal for similar reasons.
re: modal v. non-modal, still on the fence on this one, sorry. :) Steffen, thoughts?

We made the attachment wizard non modal for the reasons Sam has pointed out. It's not the optimal solution and 99% of users will never discover it but it's high value for users who know. I find it reasonable to apply the same hack here until we have a better solution.
We have argued that the attachment wizard should have a different workflow as well but no one has ever stepped up to do in the life-time of the Mylyn project so I'd rather improve make a small change now than block improvements all together.
Makes sense. Ok, I'm +1 assuming the other minor changes are made.
Fixed in 0c7cf9aa265b2b67aacaac0e262f5f0fdf7509ef
